messageBody:
I found this to be necessary, but the testing I was doing was
functional/system testing. We ended up doing our own Assert class whose
root method was this (there were convenience methods built on top of
this, so it didn't have to always be especially verbose):

void assert(String passedMessage, String failedMessage, boolean
condition);

Our TestRunner was altered to print these messages as they are being
executed, along with the test name. Be aware that I don't suggest doing
this for unit testing, as I believe the philosophy of only displaying
results when it breaks to be a good thing. But for those doing things
that aren't necessarily unit testing, it has been extremely useful.
Here's a portion of the output:

TestTestlets().testPassed(): [ PASSED 12/10/2001 02:18:28 ]
[ PASSED This will never fail ]
TestTestlets().testFailed(): [ FAILED 12/10/2001 02:18:28 ]
[ FAILED This could never succeed ]
TestTestlets().testTestletWithArgs(testing 1, 2, 3): [ PASSED 12/10/2001
02:18:28 ]
[ PASSED Msg does not equal null ]
[ got argument: "testing 1, 2, 3" ]
TestTestlets().testPassed(): [ PASSED 12/10/2001 02:18:28 ]
[ PASSED This will never fail ]
TestTestlets().testFailed(): [ FAILED 12/10/2001 02:18:28 ]
[ FAILED This could never succeed ]
TestTestlets().testErrorReporting(): [ E R R O R 12/10/2001 02:18:28 ]
[ ERROR This an emergency error of your junit system ]

-shane
